SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

PIONEER EXPERIENCES - A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name: William Ponath
2. Your address: 123 Main Street, Saskatoon
3. Date: March 15, 1955
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Dayton, Ohio, USA
5. What was your father's name and occupation?
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): August 1905
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates and reasons:
   a. Dayton, Ohio: first 11 years
   b. Other places:
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child," "I was in my teens," etc.)
9. What were your reasons for coming West? For a better opportunity of making a living.
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Mail, road or government information?)

[Handwritten note:]
Information
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? (Think many thought we were foolish.)

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)? With the family.

13. What means of transportation did you use? Railroad & within.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.).

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? We lived on Tank and Father built a small log house.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? At the N.E. Part of the Jack Wilson bury our nearest railroad.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan. I have spent about 3 yrs in Saskatoon in the spring we moved to the outskirts of Homestead in 1916 by 1914.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came? Father worked at his trade (stone mason) in summer and winter in the Slayter's house as a builder. After coming here we did some trapping and Father worked in the lumber camps.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? I think many thought we were foolish.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)? With the family.

13. What means of transportation did you use? Railroad & within.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.).

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? We lived on a small log house.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? On the N.E. part of Sec. 3, Township 3, Range 13 C.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan. I have spent about 3 yrs in Saskatoon - in spring the money & the outlook led us homesteaded in 1916 & 1914.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came? Father worked at his trade (stone mason) in summer and winter on the stage line house as a builder. After coming here we did some trapping and father worked in the lumber camps.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation? If so, where did they settle?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West, tell when they came and where they settled.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

24. How many children did you have? How many are still living?

25. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far?

26. What was your school life like? How did you feel about it?

27. Did you have any special experiences during your time here?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation? If so, where did they settle?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came next year, when they came and where they settled.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? How often? How far by what means of transportation?

25. How many times have you visited friends, etc.? How far by what means of transportation?

26. What was your school life like?
25. When was the first car used in the community? About 1914

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What makes?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)

In 1914 we got horses in the place of the open area! Did some of pitching in water!

29. How often did you shop in the early days?

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order, and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.

As far as I can remember about 1908-09

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it? About 1915

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?

I believe we intended to stay permanently from the beginning.
25. When was the first car used in the community? About 1914

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)

In 1914 we got horses in the place of the open car.

29. How often did you shop in the early days? Twice a week about every 2 months.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail other catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this manner? Indicate also what proportion of your total purchases were by mail order and any charges in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.

As far as I can remember other than 1908-1909

32. When did you first have a telephone and that company provided it at about 1915

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?

We came here intended to stay permanently.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1924? What reasons did they have for moving?

Yes, my uncle John moved away. He moved there immediately and only there. I suppose that was their purpose when they came, or maybe some were disappointed.

35. Did many people move away during the 1920s? Did many return? Yes quite a number moved away. Ralph half of them returned.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organization, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

My uncle John was on the village council for a number of years. In the thirty (1930s)

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

(Such as owning the first automobile, combining organizing the first lodge, etc.)

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in name since the first name was given, date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

Yes, most of them. They moved away because their homes were destroyed by fire.

35. Did many people move away during the 1920s? Did many return? Yes quite a number moved away. Ralph Kelly often returned.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public offices, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

My eldest brother John was on the Village Council for a number of years. In the thirties (1930s)

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here, giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combining organizing the first lodge, etc.)

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, post offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give (1) name and conception of person suggesting place-name, (2) origin and meaning of the name, (3) date of its adoption, (4) any changes in name since the first name was given, date and reason for change. Give dates of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).
39. Questions regarding historical source materials:
Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters and programs, minute books of organizations, old newspapers, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences?

One of my married sisters (Mrs. R. Jethnall)
has a large framed photograph of the Village of Nacoom taken about 1922, about 24" long which is very interesting to see as quite a number of the old timers are still living.

Would you or the person who owns them either:
(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying?
(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library, Regina, or the Archives Office at the University in Saskatoon?

.............. (indicate your preference, if any) ..............

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came west?

One of the greatest and most tragic to me is in revolution of farming methods in modern machinery which has induced many half-breed farmers to buy out the old-time farmer and then await the innovation for young farmers to start farming on account of the high prices both for land and machinery.

One of my married sisters (Mrs. R. Jettmar) has a clear photograph of the village of Naiman taken about 1923.

Would you or the person who owns them either:
(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying?
(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library? (beginning or the Archives Office of the University in Edmonton?)

One of the greatest, most tragic to me, was the revolution of farming methods in modern machinery which has induced many farmers to buy out the small farmer and then own the machinery for the third and mechanization of the high prairies.
